description:
The crash occurred on a two-way two-lane east/west rural arterial road divided by double
                        yellow lines at a T-intersection with the intersecting road coming from the north side. The
                        intersecting road was also a two-way, two-lane road that had an incline of -4 percent on the
                        southbound lane. The rural arterial road was straight and level for the most part but for a
                        slight curve from the south bending west with a radius of 148 meters. The intersection was
                        controlled by a one-way stop sign for the intersecting road. There was no traffic control device
                        for the east/west roadway. The posted speed limit was 64kmph/40mph for both roadways. Conditions
                        were partly cloudy and dry in the early afternoon on a weekend.


                        Vehicle 1, a 2001 Hyundai Santa Fe (SUV 4WD), was southbound on the intersecting road, intending
                        to make a left turn onto the east/west rural arterial road. As V1 approached the stop sign, the
                        vehicle came to a rolling stop before it began to ease out into the intersection. It then
                        contacted the trailer unit of Vehicle 2, a 1995 Ford F-350 that had a modified body with a dump
                        bed, pulling a two-axle steel framed float equipment trailer. The trailer had a bobcat track hoe
                        loaded on board that was chained down with two chains. Immediately before impact, V2 swerved
                        left in an attempt to avoid a collision. After impact it swerved left then right in an attempt
                        to get the trailer under control with the brakes locked and the tires blown on the trailer. V2
                        came to rest back in its original travel lane facing west with its load slightly askew but still
                        intact on the trailer approximately 50 meters west of POI. V1 came to rest after spinning about
                        100 degrees clockwise and was facing southwest about 4 meters west of impact. V1 was towed due
                        to damage. V2's trailer was picked up by the wrecker service, but the truck was undamaged.


                        Vehicle 1 was driven by a 33-year old belted male whose airbags deployed. He refused treatment
                        for possible injuries and only went home after the crash. The driver of V1 stated that he had
                        been reprimanded very recently for tardiness at work and was running tight on time that
                        afternoon. He also claimed to not get very much sleep regularly (5 hours per day). He said it
                        had been fourteen days since his last day off, which was a sick day and before that he can't
                        remember a day that he has been off work in recent memory.


                        The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was "This Vehicle Traveling: Turning Left at Intersection."
                        The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was a recognition error: inadequate
                        surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see). Associated factors coded to this driver
                        include fatigue, being in a hurry to get to work, a minor sightline restriction due to the heavy
                        amount of trees and shrubs, a failure to come to a complete stop at the stop sign (an illegal
                        maneuver), and work stress.


                        Vehicle 2 was driven by a 26-year old belted male who was uninjured in the crash. He was on his
                        way back to the office from a jobsite to check in the equipment and was not in any particular
                        rush that afternoon.


                        The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was "Other Vehicle Encroachment: From Crossing Street,
                        Turning Into Opposite Direction." The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not
                        coded to this vehicle. Associated factors coded to this driver were a false assumption (assumed
                        other driver would yield the right-of-way), a sight line restriction (the shrubbery on the side
                        of the road), conversation with his passenger, and traveling too fast for conditions. As per the
                        driver of V2, he was traveling between 41-50 mph at the time of the crash. The posted speed
                        limit was 40 mph.
